name: Wuxi
title: Wuxi - Traveling China like your home yard
overview: Wuxi, situated on the northern shore of the magnificent Taihu Lake, has been celebrated for over 3,000 years as one of the cradles of Wu culture in the Jiangnan region. This city of 7 million people, located just 45 minutes from Shanghai by high-speed rail, offers a more tranquil alternative to its bustling neighbor while maintaining its own distinct cultural identity. Known as the 'Pearl of Taihu Lake,' Wuxi has long been associated with prosperity and natural beauty, its name literally meaning 'without tin' — a reference to the depletion of tin mines that once made the area wealthy during ancient times. The city's most iconic landmark, the Lingshan Grand Buddha, stands 88 meters tall on the shores of Taihu Lake, making it one of the largest Buddha statues in China. This bronze colossus, surrounded by beautifully landscaped gardens and temples, has become a major pilgrimage site and tourist attraction. Nearby, the ancient Grand Buddha at Ling Shan Temple dates back over a thousand years, representing the deep Buddhist heritage that has shaped Wuxi's cultural landscape. The city's relationship with Buddhism extends to its famous clay figurines, known as Huishan clay figurines, which have been crafted in the area for over 400 years and are recognized as a national intangible cultural heritage. Wuxi's location on Taihu Lake provides stunning natural scenery that has inspired poets and painters for centuries. The lake, the third-largest freshwater lake in China, offers boating, fishing, and lakeside recreation. The nearby Huishan Ancient Town preserves traditional Jiangnan architecture with its white-walled, black-tiled houses, stone bridges, and narrow waterways. Wuxi's cuisine reflects its location in the heart of the Jiangnan region, with dishes that emphasize fresh, local ingredients and slightly sweet flavors. The famous Wuxi-style spareribs, braised until tender in a rich, sweet sauce, represent the city's culinary heritage. Whether you're seeking spiritual enlightenment at the Grand Buddha, exploring ancient water towns, or simply enjoying the gentle breezes off Taihu Lake, Wuxi offers a peaceful retreat into traditional Chinese culture.

itinerary.day: Day 1: Buddhist Wonders and Lake Views
activities: Morning: Visit the Lingshan Grand Buddha, one of the largest Buddha statues in China.
Afternoon: Take a boat tour on Taihu Lake to see the Three Immortals Penglai Island.
Evening: Stroll along Nanchang Street and enjoy the canal-side nightlife.
Morning: Explore Huishan Ancient Town for its traditional architecture and clay figurines.
Afternoon: Visit Jichang Garden, a classic Ming Dynasty garden.
Evening: Try Wuxi's famous sweet and savory spareribs at a local restaurant.
Morning: Visit the Wuxi Museum to learn about the city's history and culture.
Afternoon: Explore the ancient water town of Dangkou.
Evening: Enjoy a traditional opera performance.
